newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: SA WEEK AHEAD - SEPT CPI SEEN ABOVE EIGHT PCT.
newsitem.headline: SA WEEK AHEAD - SEPT CPI SEEN ABOVE EIGHT PCT.

text.p: The market's fruitless search for direction last week is likely to be satisfied by the release of three economic indicators this week -- CPI, money supply and trade account data.
Consumer inflation is expected to have risen above the eight percent mark in September mainly as a result of rising food prices and technical factors, economists said at the weekend.
According to a Reuters poll of 12 economists, the September consumer price index will rise 8.1 percent year-on-year or 0.7 percent month-on-month after rising 7.5 percent and 0.7 percent in August.
The consensus was drawn from a range of 7.9 to 8.2 percent.
Economists said the main concern in the latest data would be rising food prices.

"Compared to this time last year, we have not received any rain yet and we have just had a cold winter," said Huysamer Stals chief economist Johan Rossouw. "Food prices have picked up significantly in the previous month and I can't see any reason for that to change."
Meat prices in particular are expected to have risen sharply in the build up to the Christmas season.
Food prices contributed the bulk of August's increase with a 1.7 percent contribution, while the index excluding food rose just 0.2 percent from July.

Sanlam chief economist Pieter Calitz also noted another reason for higher inflation in September would be the fact that the latest figures would come off a low base. CPI rose just 0.1 percent month-on-month in September last year.
Economists also expected the quarterly survey of furniture, medical and photographic prices to contribute to the month-on-month rise.
The data will be released at 0900 GMT on Wednesday.
Money supply and private sector credit extension data is also due for release this week.

Economists forecast M3 would grow at a slower rate of 15.1 percent in September compared with a preliminary 15.51 percent in August. The average was drawn from a range of 14.4 percent to 15.8 percent.
Equisec economist Dawie Roodt said one of the main reasons money supply would ease was the fact that the data would be calculated off a high base.
M3 rose 1.5 percent month-on-month in September a year ago.

Frankel Pollak gilts analyst Tertia Jacobs was more optimistic that a build up in government deposits during the month would have drawn money out of the equation, resulting in a much slower money supply growth rate.
Private sector credit extension was expected to ease to 17.3 from 17.71 percent in August.
Economists said the main reason for the slowdown in credit extension would be the reduction in new car sales in September.
South African new car sales fell 2.4 percent to 19,928 units in September from 20,420 units in August and eased 9.5 percent from the 22,029 units sold in September 1995.
High interest rates were also expected to have taken their toll on consumers' borrowing capacity, while a high base in the same month a year ago was also expected to help.
The Reserve Bank has scheduled the data for release on Friday at 1500 GMT.

Trade data, which the South African Revenue Services said would be released from Wednesday onwards, drew predictions of a consensus forecast of a 720 million rand surplus compared with a 130 million rand surplus in August.
However, half of the economists polled were reluctant to predict the figure which they describe as too volatile and notoriously erratic.
The consensus was drawn from a range of 500 million rand to one billion rand.
Calitz said his forecast was based on general expectations that import volumes were expected to decline as a result of the weaker rand, which would in turn boost the value of South Africa's exports.
